p: Consequently, we recommend rendering the aspects of justice, e.g., the consequences for the most vulnerable people, in climate change more saliently—both in future research interventions and climate communication by political agents or the media. The current Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change [IPCC] (2022) started off strongly by consistently demanding more equitable societies. With great confidence, the authors thus declare that “solutions based on equity and social and climate justice reduce risks and enable climate resilient development” (p. 31). Climate justice is not only the ultimate goal of pro-environmental behavior, but it can also function as its elicitor by being a fundamental human motive that triggers strong moral emotions.
